events.title: Jordan joins Cranston's banking staff
events.description: She would later become his chief banking aide.

events.title: Sedlmayr begins working for DeConcini full-time
Jacobson starts working for Cranston (on Senate staff)
DeConcini meets Keating for the first time
events.description: The two meet at the Navy League dinner.

events.title: McCain meets Keating for the first time
events.description: The two meet at the Navy League dinner.

events.title: DeConcini endorses Keating for Bahamas ambassadorship in letter to President
Keating gives money to McCain's 1st House campaign
DeConcini asks Keating to help with fundraising for his '82 Senate campaign
Ed Gray becomes Chairman of the FHLBB
Keating gives money to McCain's 2nd House campaign
DeConcini's office (Sedlmayr) starts dealing with Keating
events.description: She sends messages to other senators on DeConcini's behalf.

events.title: Jacobson leaves Senate staff and becomes "Fundraising Coordinator" for Cranston
Keating arranges for contributions to retire Glenn's '84 presidential debt
McCain meets with Keating socially in Phoenix
DeConcini {writes} Cranston expressing his support to stop new FHLBB regulations
Glenn's staff {meets} with Grogan and Lincoln's lawyers regarding "direct investment" rules
Glenn sends {letter} to Gray re: dissatisfaction with proposed "direct investment" rules
Sedlmayr prepares letter to Gray requesting delay of new "direct investment" regulations
events.description: FHLBB was thinking of regulating the amount of investment thrifts could directly make in real estate ventures following the passage of S&L deregulation.

events.title: McCain sends letter to Gray on proposed "direct investment" regulation
events.description: He questions whether it is the appropriate remedy for the S&L industry.

events.title: Cranston sends {letter} to Gray on proposed "direct investment" regulation
events.description: He expresses concern and requests deferred adoption.

events.title: Cranston and Jacobson meet Grogan at Democratic National Convention
events.description: Grogan says Keating could help clear Cranston's presidential bid debt (he later sends a package of $10,000 in individual contributions).

events.title: McCain sends a follow-up {letter} to Gray on proposed "direct investment" regulations
events.description: He encloses a copy of a 1952 study by the FHLBB, which suggested that liberalization of investment powers had proved successful. He requests a full hearing on the matter.

events.title: Cranston, Jordan, and Grogan meet re: possible "direct investment" laws
Alan Greenspan attends meeting with Grogan and Cranston
events.description: He does an investigation of Lincoln and endorses their "direct investment" practices.

events.title: Alan Greenspan visits Glenn's office
events.description: He does an investigation of Lincoln and endorses their "direct investment" practices (unknown if Grogan was there).

events.title: Glenn's staff sends him a {letter} highlighting issues between Lincoln and the FHLBB
events.description: The letter notes that "Ohio is one of the affected states."

events.title: Glenn sends further {letter} to Gray re: dissatisfaction with "direct investment" proposal
DeConcini asks Keating to serve on Finance Committee of his '88 reelection campaign
DeConcini inter-office {memo} details actions Keating wants DeConcini to take to fight "direct investment" rule
events.description: DeConcini makes phone calls the next day, then follows-up with Keating.

events.title: McCain sends letter to Gray requesting an extension of the comment period on the "direct investment" proposal
FHLBB promulgates "direct investment" rule
events.description: Under the new rule, effective April 16th, the amount of "direct investment" that a thrift would be allowed to make will be tied to its net worth. Formerly, institutions with a relatively low level of net worth could make "direct investment" up to 10% of net assets without obtaining regulatory approval.

events.title: Glenn and DeConcini send a joint {letter} to Gray criticizing "direct investment" rule
events.description: They propose that the FHLBB defer acting on regulations until June.

events.title: Cranston sends {letter} to Gray requesting an extension of the comment period on the "direct investment" proposal
{Media:} Everything's Black and White When It Comes to Ed Gray
events.description: "Mortgage-industry insiders are still talking about the performance that savings and loan regulatory czar Edwin J. Gray gave last March before a prestigious group of about 100 industry executives regarding "direct investment" laws.

events.title: Greenspan releases {letter} supporting Lincoln's bid to avoid "direct investment" rule
events.description: Lincoln was seeking an exemption from the FHLBB's new rule.

events.title: Keating and Grogan organize a fundraiser for Cranston
events.description: $15,000 is raised from the event.

events.title: DeConcini writes letters to the Treasury secretary re: various complaints about Gray
events.description: He writes Keating and lets him know that he has made these complaints.

events.title: Keating contributes to a political action committee (PAC) that Glenn is the spokesman for
events.description: $200,000 is donated to the PAC.

events.title: Keating attempts to hire Gray out of regulatory post (as FHLBB Chairman)
events.description: Gray responds by reporting Keating to the Justice Department.

events.title: Keating becomes "significant" contributor to Cranston
events.description: This is according to aide Joy Jacobson.

events.title: Keating gives money to McCain's 1st Senate campaign
events.description: Keating offers to raise more, but McCain declines. Over four campaigns, Keating will contribute $4,000 personally with another $112,000 coming from his family and friends.

events.title: McCain sends letters to White House Chief of Staff Baker and Treasury Secretary Regan containing copies of his 01/04/1985 letter
events.description: He requests their assistance in the "direct investment" rule matter.

events.title: Jacobson opens $300,000 line of credit from Lincoln
events.description: This is to finance Cranston's '86 re-election campaign. Cranston faced a campaign debt of $2 million from his '84 presidential campaign and had to quickly gear up for an expensive and competitive re-election battle in '86.

events.title: Keating again contributes to a political action committee (PAC) that Glenn is the spokesman for
events.description: $100,000 is donated to the PAC.

events.title: Riegle meets Keating at the opening of his Pontchartrain Hotel in Detroit
events.description: Glenn tells Riegle to go and meet Keating as a potential funder. They do not talk about Lincoln's problems.

events.title: Keating asks Glenn to support nomination of Lee Henkel to Bank Board
events.description: Glenn refuses.

events.title: Media: Earnings, Revenue Rise 30% for Lincoln Savings
Media: FHLBB's Gray Fights On; S&L Officials No Longer Pressing for His Resignation
events.description: "The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, ankle-deep in rumors that he would announce his resignation, stood at a lectern in Dallas last November while looking across an audience of the thrift industry's top executives."

events.title: DeConcini recommends Henkel to be on the FHLBB
events.description: Keating suggests him and DeConcini writes Riegle about it. Sedlmayr notes that these requests are unusual.

events.title: Keating asks Glenn to support the nomination of Daniel Manion to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
events.description: Glenn refuses.

events.title: Keating, Grogan, and Riegle meet briefly re: ACC
events.description: ACC is Keating's primary corporation and the parent company of Lincoln.

events.title: McCain {writes} Gray about delaying implementation of "direct investment" regulations
Media: EARNINGS; Lincoln S&L Reports 50% Income Drop
events.description: "Lincoln Savings & Loan Assn. reported that its net income for the second quarter fell more than 50% to $11.9 million from $24.1 million in the same quarter last year. Revenues in the quarter rose 38.7% to $193.8 million from $139.7 million in last."

events.title: Keating sends {letter} to McCain disparaging Gray
events.description: Marked "CONFIDENTIAL". Calls the FHLBB, under Gray, "a 'Mad Dog' turned loose in a police state effort."

events.title: DeConcini receives checks raised by Keating
events.description: The checks total $16,000; DeConcini says he is aware of these only after the '86 election.

events.title: Keating, Grogan, and Riegle meet re: Henkel nomination
Sedlmayr becomes aware of Keating's trouble with the Bank Board
events.description: She says this is due to media on the matter.

events.title: Media: FHLBB Officials' Special Treatment Probed
events.description: "Four top officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board are receiving special treatment that gives two of them salaries that are thousands of dollars above the federal pay cap and provides the other two with job security unavailable to most top officials."

events.title: Gray releases {statement} about Keating's attempts to hire Gray out of FHLBB role
events.description: Offered him "some sort of public relations job at Lincoln."

events.title: Gray sends {letter} to Cirona requesting information on Lincoln review
events.description: This is because of "The Washington Post" article that "the Bank Board is harassing" the company.

events.title: {Cirona Report} is issued to Gray as response to his earlier letter
events.description: Outlines in great detail all the problems that the FHLB-SF had with ACC. Contentious because Gray's statement at the first meeting of "I don't know anything" was a lie.

events.title: FSLIC recapitalization bill is stopped in Congress by Speaker Wright
events.description: He signals to the Bank Board that Congressional consent will be key to future regulatory efforts.

events.title: Jacobson meets with Keating on '86 election night
Media: Lincoln Savings Reports 70% Gain in Profit for Third Quarter
{Media:} Gray Reimbursed Home Loan Banks for Wife's Travels
events.description: "Federal Home Loan Bank Board Chairman Edwin J. Gray on Tuesday made public hundreds of pages of his expense and travel records for meetings ranging from Florida to Hawaii, along with a memo saying that the furor over payment of his wife's travel expenses should subside as he always repaid voluntarily."

events.title: Media: Bank Board Lived Well Off S&Ls; Industry Picked Up Tab for Cruises, Gifts, Alcohol, Limousines - Bank Board's Expenses Disclosed
DeConcini sends Sedlmayr memo about putting pressure on Gray
events.description: This is evidence that DeConcini wanted to influence Gray well before the April meetings.

events.title: Sedlmayr advises DeConcini to "stay out of" the Gray/Keating feud
events.description: She does this in a memo to DeConcini.

events.title: Jacobson sends {memo} to Cranston re: legislative matters of contributors
events.description: The memo includes a section on Keating.

events.title: Media: Bank Board Appointee Faces Conflict Charge; Proxmire Opposes Henkel for S&L Ties; Bank Board Appointee Faces Conflict Charge by Proxmire
events.description: "Lee Henkel, who joined the Federal Home Loan Bank Board two months ago via a recess appointment by President Reagan, is embroiled in a conflict-of-interest charge that lies at the heart of a fight over control of the Bank Board and ultimately the future of the ailing S&L industry."

events.title: Media: Henkel Denies Conflict in His S&L Proposal
events.description: "At Mr. Henkel's first Board meeting, on Dec. 18th, the board rejected a proposal by its Chairman, Edwin J. Gray, to extend for two years a rule limiting a thrift institutions' direct real estate investments to 10 percent of its assets... Mr. Henkel then proposed a more liberal plan that included exempting certain thrift institutions from the retroactive impact of the rule. His plan was also voted down. After the meeting, staff members said privately that only two institutions, one of them Lincoln Savings, would have benefited from the Henkel plan."

events.title: Henkel sends {letter} to Proxmire defending his actions on the FHLBB
events.description: "I made the proposal in good faith, believing it to be a general industry problem." "Not public info." is written on the first page.

events.title: Riegle meets with Keating and Grogan in Washington
events.description: Fundraising event on Riegle's behalf is discussed (possibly at the Pontchartrain Hotel, where Keating was investing in another tower).

events.title: Glenn meets with Atchison to discuss investigation of Keating
events.description: Glenn sets this up to substantiate Lincoln's claims that regulators are being abusive and that Glenn should talk with them.

events.title: McCain goes to Riegle's office to talk about the Gray/Keating feud
Riegle's staff drafts a {memo} for him detailing a fundraising opportunity with Keating
events.description: Expects to raise $100,000 to $125,000 through Keating.

events.title: Media: Lincoln S&L Holds Position as No. 2 in Orange County
America Votes - a Cranston-affiliated PAC advocating voter participation - discloses Keating donated $100,000 in seed funding
events.description: The check is cut on Mar. 3rd. Jacobson keeps Grogan up-to-date with the PAC's activity.

events.title: Letter sent to Jacobson from Grogan re: desire for Gray's dismissal
events.description: Grogan wants their advice on the matter; Jacobson says she doesn't remember seeing it.

events.title: Grogan sends {letter} to Riegle, Jacobson, and Jordan asking for advice about a Senate "Petition for Disqualification" for Gray
Lincoln's lawyers release {letter} defending actions of Henkel
events.description: "The problems of the thrift industry did not occur on Mr. Henkel's watch."

events.title: Grogan and Atchison go to Washington to lobby support for "direct investment" deregulation.
events.description: They meet with McCain and Riegle.

events.title: Lincoln files lawsuit against FHLBB "direct investment" laws
events.description: Lincoln loses in court.

events.title: Keating calls DeConcini and asks him to set up meeting re: issues with Gray
events.description: This is not the only time DeConcini had been contacted by Keating re: Gray. DeConcini thinks a meeting is a good idea.

events.title: Riegle talks to McCain on Senate floor re: Keating's issues
events.description: They go to Riegle's office after to discuss.

events.title: AZ League of Savings and Loans Association issues complaint to VanPaasschen re: "direct investment" laws
Riegle meets with Gray re: FSLIC recapitalization bill
events.description: Secretary says Gray's office called Riegle to set up meeting.

events.title: Gray meets with Riegle to lobby for "direct investment" regulation
events.description: At the end of the meeting, Riegle tells Gray that there are senators that want to meet with him about the "direct investment" laws. According to Gray, Riegle says, "You'll be getting a call."

events.title: Riegle visits Lincoln in Phoenix
events.description: At the end of the visit, Riegle says he will try to set up a meeting with Gray. He also offers that it would help to have constituent senators present. During the later investigation, Riegle says that the trip to Phoenix was on the pretense of another engagement.

events.title: While Keating and Riegle meet privately, Grogan works on fundraiser that Keating proposed for Riegle
events.description: It is to be held at the Pontchartrain Hotel in Detroit.

events.title: Riegle votes against cutting S&L regulatory funding
Arthur Young (Atchison's) letter sent to Riegle by Atchison
{Media:} Bank Board Clears Henkel of Conflict Charge; Reagan Nominee Accused of Proposing Self-Serving Amendment
events.description: "The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has cleared Board member Lee Henkel of conflict-of-interest charges concerning a California savings and loan institution the Federal agency regulates, according to an internal bank board document."

events.title: Grogan attends meeting with Cranston and Riegle
events.description: The group talk about America Votes, a Cranston-affiliated PAC advocating voter participation.

events.title: DeConcini's office receives Atchison's letter and other evidence of mistreatment from ACC
events.description: The Arthur Young letter was originally sent to Riegle.

events.title: Arthur Young (Atchison's) letter sent to McCain's office
events.description: VanPaasschen says she is unaware of the office receiving the letter; it is not clear who sent it.

events.title: ACC sends DeConcini's office information re: regulatory problems and ACC's responses
events.description: Includes memo entitled "Talking Points for Meeting with Ed Gray." Written on it: "WONT USE."

events.title: DeConcini talks to Riegle and tells him he is having trouble with Gray
events.description: DeConcini asks him if he will help; Riegle later suggests having meeting with Gray.

events.title: Grogan meets with Riegle and asks for invite from McCain/DeConcini to attend meeting with Gray
events.description: This is allegedly when Riegle tells Grogan to have DeConcini invite him.

events.title: Sedlmayr prepares memo re: ACC's concerns for DeConcini
events.description: ACC had sent DeConcini's office a bunch of material; Sedlmayr summarizes and adds editorial to it for DeConcini (she believes she did this before meeting with McCain).

events.title: McCain, DeConcini, VanPaasschen, and Sedlmayr meet in McCain's office re: Keating and Gray
events.description: Discussed Keating's problems with audit and whether a meeting with Gray would be productive. McCain doesn't commit to DeConcini's suggestion to go to the SF regulators. DeConcini offers to go to Gray's office right there and then. McCain tells VanPaasschen afterwards he thinks that is inappropriate.

events.title: VanPaasschen advises McCain that meeting with Gray and the SF regulators would be improper
DeConcini receives summary of Keating's positions via "Schedule" {memo}
events.description: Memo is written by Sedlmayr.

events.title: DeConcini calls Gray and asks if he will meet with the senators re: Lincoln's problems with the Bank Board
events.description: Gray says he will be happy to and they set the time. "No aides" was not mentioned in the conversation.

events.title: Petition filed to recuse Gray from the Bank Board
events.description: It is filed by Lincoln.

events.title: Fundraiser by Keating for Riegle held at his Pontchartrain Hotel
VanPaasschen has long conversation with Atchison about the legitimacy of his letter
events.description: She ends the conversation believing in his sincerity.

events.title: Sedlmayr tells VanPaasschen that Keating called McCain a "wimp" in conversation with DeConcini
DeConcini meets with Keating
events.description: They discuss the upcoming meeting with Gray.

events.title: Keating and McCain meet in McCain's office
events.description: McCain tells Keating he won't intervene for him; the two have a falling out.

events.title: VanPaasschen sends {memo} to McCain that supports Arthur Young letter (after meeting with Keating)
events.description: Memo includes information that she got from Atchison. According to McCain, this research happens during the meeting with Keating (when McCain says he won't talk to Gray for him).

events.title: McCain terminates relationship with Keating
Riegle votes again on the Senate floor to protect funding for S&L regulators
McCain tells VanPaasschen that there is discussion of four senators meeting with Gray
events.description: Names the four senators that will be involved; says DeConcini agreed to discussion points.

events.title: Media: Justice Asked to Probe Bank Board Member; Justice Asked to Probe Henkel
events.description: "The Justice Department has been asked to determine if a top savings and loan regulator used his government office to try to benefit an S&L [Lincoln] that has lent him millions of dollars."

events.title: Sedlmayr sends DeConcini {memo} in preparation for April 2nd meeting
events.description: This is done at the request of DeConcini.

events.title: Date when McCain says he finds out other senators will be at the April 2nd meeting with Gray
{Media:} Henkel Resigns FHLBB Post, Criticizes Justice Dept. Probe [of Relationship With Lincoln]; Henkel Quits Bank Board
Meeting 1: McCain, DeConcini, Cranston, and Glenn meet with Gray in DeConcini's office
events.description: First of the Keating Five meetings; VanPaasschen sits outside and Riegle is not in attendance. According to Gray, Riegle first summonsed him to this meeting.

events.title: McCain receives {memo} outlining two points he can talk about in meeting with Gray (from VanPaasschen)
Keating sends "Schedule" memo to other senators
Grogan goes to Washington after the first meeting to talk to all the senators and "keep the team together
events.description: Keating tells him to "keep the team together" and tell all the senators how important attendance at the second meeting is to Keating.

events.title: Gray calls DeConcini to tell him that the SF regulators will be available to meet with the senators on the 9th
events.description: DeConcini's office calls the other senators' schedulers to let them know.

events.title: Riegle tells DeConcini to ask Sedlmayr not to contact his office re: meetings with Gray
events.description: Riegle's scheduler said he knew nothing about Riegle's involvement with the Gray meeting.

events.title: Sedlmayr calls friend in Riegle's office to find out about his involvement in the matter
events.description: The friend says he knows nothing about the meeting. DeConcini tells Sedlmayr that Riegle asked her not to contact his office about the matter.

events.title: DeConcini calls Gray and tells him the senators do want to meet with the SF regulators
events.description: Gray sets up the meeting.

events.title: Sedlmayr drafts {letter} to Riegle inviting him to second meeting, from DeConcini and McCain
events.description: Letter is only signed by DeConcini; Sedlmayr later testified she thought the letter was unusual as it was her impression that the meeting was Riegle's idea.

events.title: Meeting 2: Keating Five meet with SF regulators in DeConcini's office
events.description: McCain only asks about length of exam and fairness; Cranston attends only part of the meeting due to business on the Senate floor.

events.title: Sedlmayr meets with Grogan on the day of the April 9th meeting
Both McCain and Glenn end all contact with Keating and SF regulators
Jordan visits ACC (to look at their operation and land valuation, etc.)
events.description: Invited by Grogan and paid for by CA Thrift and Loan, who she was making a speech for.

events.title: DeConcini calls Keating and tells him he can't expect much from the Bank Board
Gray sends Riegle copy of the Black Transcript
Riegle ends all contact with Keating and SF regulators
events.description: Except to later return contributions raised by Keating in early '88.

events.title: Riegle {calls} a New York City security company Gray is interested in a job with and gives a positive opinion
Exam Report on Lincoln issued by SF regulators
Gray's term on the Bank Board ends
events.description: M. Danny Wall is appointed the new Chairman.

events.title: Keating offers to raise another $150,000 for Glenn
events.description: Glenn declines Keating's offer.

events.title: Keating sends Grogan infamous "Get Black" {letter}
events.description: Claims that if Grogan "can't get Wright and Congress to get Black - kill him dead - [he] ought to retire."

events.title: Media: S&L Chief Says Bank Board Leaked Data to Discredit Him; S&L Executive Sues Bank Board
events.description: "A California savings and loan executive who has feuded for years with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has filed suit accusing the agency of leaking confidential financial information to discredit him and ruin his business."

events.title: Jacobson schedules {meeting} with Keating and Cranston for this date
events.description: Jacobson says Keating is happy about Wall being appointed the new FHLBB Chairman. She then suggests that Cranston "should ask Keating for $250,000."

events.title: Jordan hears Bank Board is making a criminal referral to the Justice Department re: Lincoln
events.description: She says she read it in "National Thrift News".

events.title: Glenn sets up a luncheon between Keating, Wright, and himself
Jacobson schedules dinner for Cranston and Keating
events.description: Keating surprises Cranston with $500,000 in donation checks.

events.title: "National Thrift News" ranks Lincoln 39th of top 100 S&Ls in net worth
Riegle's staff drafts a {memo} for him detailing another fundraising opportunity with Keating
events.description: Keating would be expected to raise $100,000. "We know Keating can produce this," Gottlieb writes.

events.title: Keating sends {letter} to Cranston's son Kim thanking him and Cranston for meeting with ACC staff in Phoenix earlier that month
events.description: The letter notes that Keating would like to meet again with Kim in either Hong Kong or Phoenix.

events.title: Sedlmayr receives Black Transcript
Sedlmayr sends DeConcini {memo} defending actions he has taken on Lincoln's behalf
events.description: In context, Sedlmayr says that support for Lincoln is not out of line.

events.title: Cranston and Grogan talk via telephone about Lincoln
Riegle sends a handwritten {note} to Keating thanking him for his support during the '88 reelection campaign
ACC {hires} Atchison
events.description: According to the press, for an annual salary of $930,000.

events.title: Jordan sends {memo} to Cranston re: phone call with SF regulators
events.description: SF regulators confirm what she heard from Grogan re: the fact that they are taking aggressive action despite fraud admissions.

events.title: Bank Board and Lincoln enter into public Memorandum of Understanding
SF regulators {deny} that Gray was in any way involved with FHLB-SF investigation of Lincoln
events.description: In response to letter from Gray requesting clarification after media coverage.

events.title: {Media:} THE SAVINGS AND LOAN CRISIS; Edwin Gray on the S&L Crisis 'This Was a Self-Inflicted Disaster'
{Media:} Savings & Loans & Intrigue & 'Meddling'
events.description: "What was once a dirty little secret is now headline news: The American taxpayer will have to foot a bill, estimated at between $50 billion and $100 billion, to pay for the profligate pursuits of savings and loan operators."

events.title: Keating calls DeConcini to make request (DeConcini says no)
events.description: Asks for DeConcini to call new FHLBB Chairman Wall and see if he will hold the audit and push for approval of Lincoln's sale. Keating needs more time to sell the company to keep ACC viable. Instead, DeConcini just makes a status inquiry.

events.title: Jordan, Cranston, and Keating have dinner
events.description: Keating says he's getting out of the business.

events.title: DeConcini sends Sedlmayr memo re: sale of Lincoln
events.description: DeConcini seems to express genuine concern about overall state of the AZ economy (not writing just as a political favor to Keating).

events.title: Keating sends DeConcini a {note} asking for money for an anti-pornography group, acknowledging that "it seems like [he is] asking an awful lot of favors lately
events.description: DeConcini writes on note to aide: "Pls draft letter to Goldwater & AG & with copy (blind) Keating. Mention pornography & my strong stand. Dennis." The letter was sent sometime in 1989 - the exact date is unknown.

events.title: Jordan, DeConcini, Gottlieb (a Riegle aide), Sedlmayr, Cranston and Grogan meet in DeConcini's office re: sale of Lincoln.
events.description: Grogan talks about Lincoln's intent to sell; he is seeking help in getting the Bank Board to approve the sale.

events.title: Jordan calls Dochow (FHLBB Regulation Supervisor)
events.description: She wants to check on why the Bank Board is involved in selling this early (if Lincoln is a healthy company, as she thought). Dochow says Lincoln's net worth is in dispute.

events.title: Sedlmayr sends memo to DeConcini re: meeting with Grogan
events.description: Grogan wants DeConcini to push for approval of the sale of Lincoln.

events.title: DeConcini {calls} new FHLBB Chairman Wall and other members
events.description: He uses Sedlmayr's talking points for the call.

events.title: VanPaasschen writes {memo} to McCain summarizing the Lincoln case
events.description: She gives background information and states reasons why it was fine for McCain to be involved.

events.title: McCain sends {letter} to Gray asking if his actions were improper
Sedlmayr drafts response to Gray-McCain letter for DeConcini
Gray {responds} to McCain's letter
events.description: He appreciates McCain writing earnestly, but says that he was in the wrong.

events.title: DeConcini sends {letter} to Gray
events.description: He says Gray's response to McCain's letter is bogus.

events.title: McCain {responds} to Gray's response
events.description: He basically says that the two will have to agree to disagree.

events.title: Gray {responds} to DeConcini's letter
events.description: He basically calls DeConcini a liar.

events.title: Cranston sends {letter} to Gray
events.description: He says that Gray's response to McCain's letter is "curious" and bogus.

events.title: {Media:} THE $150 BILLION CALAMITY; Hardening the S&L Battle Lines 'You Can't Restrict Our God-Given Right to Make Profits!'
DeConcini sends {note} to Sedlmayr about damage control
events.description: Asks Sedlmayr to start "right away" and "discredit Gray."

events.title: Gray {responds} to Cranston's letter
events.description: He basically calls Cranston a liar.

events.title: Cranston sends {letter} to "The Wall Street Journal" responding to allegations of impropriety
events.description: He casts his involvement as limited and constituent service-based.

events.title: McCain calls Gray about letters
An FHLBB member writes a {letter} in support of DeConcini and Cranston
McCain releases press {statement} regarding his involvement with ACC
events.description: He notes that ACC is a major employer in AZ and that he attended on his own free will.

events.title: {Media:} $1.1 Billion Bank Fraud Suit Filed; New Rescue Agency Accuses S&L Owner of Racketeering, U.S. Regulators File Suit Against Calif. S&L Owner
events.description: "Federal banking regulators yesterday filed the biggest bank fraud lawsuit ever, accusing Arizona real estate developer Charles Keating and his associates of directing a racketeering scheme that destroyed..."

events.title: DeConcini releases {statement} denying that a vote for military aid for the Contras was in exchange for White House appointment of a Keating-friendly individual to the FHLBB
{Media:} Auditors Of Lincoln On the Spot; Auditor's Letter to a Senator; Advocacy Role Questioned
Riegle's attorneys release lengthy {letter} denying his involvement with Lincoln
events.description: They call it "very limited."

events.title: DeConcini returns Keating's contributions
events.description: He does so after the Federal government files a lawsuit charging civil fraud; this was a campaign-wide policy of his in instances like this.

events.title: Cranston releases press {statement} alleging impropriety on Gray's part
Cranston {announces} introduction of legislation to protect those who lost savings in Lincoln collapse
Media: Keating, Failed King of Thrifts, Lincoln S&L's Deposed Chief, Blasting Back at the Regulators
events.description: "Federal officials say the taxpayer bailout of Keating's bankrupt Lincoln Savings and Loan - one of hundreds of failed thrifts nationwide - could cost every man, woman, and child in America $10 each."

events.title: {Media:} Who to Thank for the Thrift Crisis
events.description: "The industry owes its troubles to Congress, regulators - and itself."

events.title: {Media:} Key Senators Seek Slow Growth of Troubled S&Ls
events.description: "Proxmire, Garn Want Quick Action to Prevent More Losses."

events.title: {Media:} Mr. Ed's Revenge
events.description: Once the Washington Press Corps Mocked Ed Gray. But Then He Helped Topple the Speaker of the House and Put Alan Cranston on the Run.

events.title: {Media:} Former Sen. William Proxmire was never tempted by campaign...
events.description: "Former Sen. William Proxmire was never tempted by campaign contributions, especially from cash-laden special interests anxious to please the banking committee chairman, because he felt such money struck at the heart of political corruption."
